description: The start of April could bring the warmest weather of the year so far - but will it last?
title: Spring warmth to return as temperatures could hit 22C this week
title_page: Spring warmth to return as temperatures could hit 22C this week - BBC Weather
maintext:
April arrives this week and it looks set to bring a burst of spring warmth.
High pressure and a feed of south-easterly winds could lift temperatures to 22C (72F) in some places.
Largely dry conditions are expected with plenty of sunshine.
It is possible that we could see the UK's warmest weather of the year so far but there is uncertainty about just how warm it will get - and how long it might last.
As high pressure moves north-eastwards during Monday and Tuesday the wind direction will change - from westerly to south-easterly.
This will bring a feed of dry and warm air from continental Europe which should gradually clear most of the cloud, allowing for more blue sky and sunshine.
Temperatures will also climb and are expected to peak between Wednesday and Friday depending on where you are located.
With chilly seas around the UK right now (just 7- 11 Celsius), anywhere exposed to a brisk onshore breeze will see temperature rise somewhat limited.
Some areas sheltered from the breeze, or under light winds, could reach 20 to 22C (68-72F) - potentially the highest temperatures of the year so far.
The current maximum for 2025 came on the spring equinox - 20 March - when Northolt (London) and Chertsey (Surrey) saw highs of 21.3C (70.3F).
Warm, dry weather is not good news for everyone though.
High pollen levels will mean tricky conditions for some hay fever sufferers, and with the sun gaining strength at this time of year, UV levels are likely to be moderate.
Gardeners may also need to be wary of the continuing threat of chilly nights and occasional frosts.
